Guide for All Developers

Wiki ▸ Guide for All Developers

Guide for All Developers

Ken Shimizu wrote this in his piece you can find over at [[Jobs Success Stories]] that explains the amount you just don’t know still coming out of DBC.

When I first started working, there were so many factors around writing code that I didn’t know, that it was hard for me to focus on coding itself. Learning the domain model, estimation, design collaboration, git flow, and a deployment process, all while trying to show your technical worth can be hard. It took me months to learn all these little skills, but if you can learn some of them before entering the workforce, you can really hit the ground running! Not only that, but you’ll be able to talk about them knowledgeably at an interview, improving your chances of getting hired.

Continual Learning

Learning doesn’t stop at DBC. Here’s some more topics to start tackling for your software career.

  • Upgrade Your Terminal
    • Bash
    • ZSH
    • Fish
    • Vim
  • Technical Debt
  • Git Workflow
  • Design by Contract
  • OO & OOD
    • SOLID Principles
    • Object Interfaces
  • Deep Dive - Algorithms
  • Virtual Machines

Additional Resources

Blogs

  • Hacker News - Not technically a blog, but social news for software developers. Has taken the place of so many predecessors like Slashdot
  • Engineering Blogs - A super list of Engineering Firm’s blogs that has something for everyone, no matter if you’re a data scientist, a front-end developer, or a designer. Credits to Oli Treadwell for finding this resource.

Websites

  • Insights Data Engineering - Webpage describing more technology tools, like file systems and nosql databases.
  • Startup Stash - A curated directory of resources & tools to help you build your Startup
  • Bento - Learn to code and what to code next - a grid of technologies and tools to research to learn as a developer.
  • Sliced Ham - Engineering stories voted up and down like Reddit.

Podcasts

Want to continue learning about tech outside of DBC or work? Podcasts have become a great medium for learning more about anything you want, including programming. Feel free to continue contributing to this list.

Developers

DevChat.tv
  • Ruby Rogues - A weekly roundtable panel show talking about Ruby and other full-stack web development. Charles Max Wood, the show and network’s creator, usually hosts the show, although not always.
  • Javascript Jabber
  • iPhreaks
  • Freelancers’ Show
  • Adventures in Angular
  • RailsClips
Live Streams
  • Livecoding.tv
Selected Episodes
  • Matt Mullenweg Interview on The Tim Ferris Show
Other Shows
  • Code Newbie Podcast - Hosted by Saron Yibarek who runs Code Newbie interviews different type of developers, from developers like Zed Shaw of Coding the Hard Way book series to new developers. Also check out Code Club, a place to host a small, virtual hangout to learn something new.
  • SVG Immersion Podcast - Rob Levin of Mavenlink hosts this show with a guest to talk sometimes about SVG, but almost always about front-end development and UI/UX.
  • Build Podcast

Technology News

TWiT.tv Network

Used to be a huge TWiT fan, so I’ve included some of their best-of shows.

  • This Week in Tech - A weekly roundtable commentary of the week’s tech news.
  • Tech News Today - A daily round-up show of tech news.
  • Security Now - A security specific tech show of security news.
  • Triangulation - An interview show with luminary minds in tech.
The Verge
  • The Vergecast

Other Shows

  • Daily Tech News Show
  • Foundation - A interview series with founders and entrepreneurs. Hosted by Kevin Rose.

Reading

  • The Pragmatic Programmer - If you didn’t read this before or during your DBC experience, you should read this book. It goes through a slew of things you did at DBC like refactoring, testing, DRY, and debugging, but it also has things on estimation, design by contract, and power editing. Basically, it’s not a book you read once. You return back to it after working and start to write programs differently after you’ve worked on a few projects.
  • Code Complete: A Practical Handbook of Software Construction - Microsoft’s book on writing clean code, over a decade old. Recommended by most programmers I’ve met.
  • Coders At Work - Interviews with successful programmers. From the same series as Founders At Work

Technology World

I don’t know where to put there (ever-growing) list of books I have about technology. They really might not be pertinent to the world of being a developer, but none-the-less, I read too many books to count anyways.

  • The Innovator’s Dilemma: The Revolutionary Book That Will Change the Way You Do Business
  • Hatching Twitter: A True Story of Money, Power, Friendship, and Betrayal
  • The Everything Store: Jeff Bezos and the Age of Amazon
Entrepreneurship
  • Founders At Work - Jessica Levingston interviews start-up entrepreneurs who grew their companies big. More about business in tech than in the technical details.
Start-ups
  • The Lean Startup: How Today’s Entrepreneurs Use Continuous Innovation to Create Radically Successful Businesses - Eric Ries describes his failed startup and what he has learned from advising other startups and watch them grow. He’s working on a new book now, funded by backers on Kickstarter, so you should check it out.
  • Zero to One: Notes on Startups, or How to Build the Future - Based on Peter Thiel’s Stanford course and notes, the book goes through some trends Thiel has seen in the start-ups he invests in.
  • Venture Capitalists at Work: How VCs Identify and Build Billion-Dollar Successes

Communities

  • While technically not a book, Brick By Brick is an online guide on how to build your own online community.

Welcome ye all who have found the Post-DBC Resources guide. This section are resources to get you started for your Post-DBC life. We're using the Wiki instead of contributing to the Repository. That way, anyone who joins can make without having to do commits (we're not official here).
